en: Opening of Wrocław European Capital of Culture 2016 - 17 January

The year-long celebration of art and culture that is the European Capital of Culture kicks off on the weekend of 15-17 January in Wrocław, Poland. On 17 January, the opening ceremony will be held with a concert dedicated to the works of composer Iannis Xenakis.
58-Document for general distribution (intended for the general public)
On 17 January, the opening ceremony of Wrocław 2016 will be held with a concert dedicated to the works of composer Iannis Xenakis.

Wrocław joins Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain, as the European Capital of Culture host city for 2016.

Opening ceremony

The ceremony will begin at 12pm (local time) on Sunday 17 January at Wrocław's National Forum of Music.

The ceremony will combine the official opening and a symphony concert consisting of two musical works by Iannis Xenakis, Ata and Jonchaies, conducted by Ernst Kovaćic.

To mark the beginning of a fantastic year for Wrocław, speeches will be given by:

  • Andrzej Duda, the President of Poland
  • Tibor Navaracsics, the European Commissioner for Education, Culture, Youth and Sport
  • Piotr Glínski, Poland's Minister of Culture and National Heritage
  • Rafal Dutkiewicz, Mayor of Wrocław
  • Krzysztof Maj, General Director of ECOC Wrocław 2016

The ceremony will close about 3pm, before Awakening, the climax of Wrocław's opening, gets underway.

Awakening - the Four Spirits of Wrocław

Awakening is the most important event of the opening weekend. Under the leadership of the Four Spirits - the Spirit of Religious Diversity, the Spirit of Innovation, the Spirit of Restoration, and the Spirit of the Flood – parades will head to the Market Square from four points across the city with the aim of metaphorically "awakening" different parts of the city.

Each parade will be an enormous artistic show. Awakening will feature over 1,300 artists and 200 choir singers, 50 soldiers, 20 orchestra members, 300 cyclists, 30 light installations, over 1,400 costumes, 30 gigantic puppets, and 5 trams.

The week-end festivities will also include the opening of a great exhibition of works by Eduardo Chillida, an artist born in San Sebastian, the second 2016 European Capital of Culture, as well as the vernissage of the "Made in Europe. 25 years of the European Union prize for contemporary architecture – Mies van der Rohe" exhibition.
